Way Back Wednesday: Saint Louis Art Museum is featuring this photo taken in 1954 in what is now our North Side Early Childhood Center. The year 1954 is special -- and this darling diverse group of children -- because that is when our nation's classrooms were racially desegrated by order of the US Supreme Court.

Fun fact: Board member Dr. Alison Nash has a sister who attended the Nursery Foundation's Preschool housed in the building back then. We THINK (can't say for sure) that's her in front wearing the smocked dress.

The Nursery Foundation graciously donated the building to us to begin our Early Childhood Center in 2011.

post_text: Did you know that Halloween was thought to be started by the Celts in northern Europe in 200 B.C.? This day marked the end of summer and the harvest and the beginning of the dark, cold winter, a time of year that was often associated with humans leaving the earth. Celts believed that on the night before the new year, the boundary between the worlds of the living and the dead became blurred. On the night of October 31 they celebrated Samhain, when it was believed that the ghosts of the dead returned to earth. Spooky, isn't it?

text:
Missouri Day is set apart in statute to commemorate Missouri history with activities and learning. The people of Missouri are requested to devote some part of the day to explore the products of our mines, fields, and forests and the achievements of Missourians in commerce, literature, politics, science, art, and in other services to humanity. Let's hear it for the Show-Me State!
